channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Hurricane Ida: Louisiana hunkers down as 'catastrophic' storm strikes
item.description: Forecasters say the storm, which has now made landfall, is extremely dangerous.

item.title: Afghanistan: US drone strike 'eliminates airport bomb threat'
item.description: The strike on a vehicle prevented another suicide bombing by Islamic State, military officials say.

item.title: Bodies of US troops killed in Kabul returned to America
item.description: A "dignified transfer" ceremony takes place at Dover Air Force Base, Delaware, to receive their remains.

item.title: Ed Asner: Lou Grant and Up actor dies aged 91
item.description: He'll be remembered for his roles as TV newsman Lou Grant and the lead voice role in Pixar hit Up.

item.title: Mountain lion: US mother fights off animal attacking her son
item.description: She hit the animal with her bare hands as it attacked the five-year-old at their home in California.

item.title: Jamaican soul of reggae Lee 'Scratch' Perry dies aged 85
item.description: Perry, a legendary singer and music producer, is known for his pioneering experiments with dub.

item.title: Yemen war: Drone attack on government airbase kills 30 soldiers
item.description: Pro-government forces say Houthi rebels targeted the base with missiles and armed drones.

item.title: Possum skin cloaks: Reviving an Aboriginal cultural tradition
item.description: Indigenous people in south-east Australia are reviving an expression of cultural identity.

item.title: Wife of murdered Greek ambassador jailed over his death in Brazil
item.description: Françoise de Souza Oliveira was found guilty of planning the murder with her lover, who confessed.

item.title: Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro says he will be killed, arrested or re-elected
item.description: Brazil's right-wing president is trying to rally support ahead of next year's election.

item.title: Emotional arrival for Afghan Paralympians in Tokyo
item.description: The safe arrival of Afghanistan's Paralympic athletes in Tokyo sends out "a very strong message of hope", says the International Paralympic Committee.

item.title: Europe migrant crisis: More than 500 people rescued off Italian island
item.description: Italian coastguards rescue 539 people from a small fishing boat believed to have set off from Libya.

item.title: French woman arrested over jewellery thefts from coffins
item.description: Police believe the woman was posing as a mourner to strip valuables from the recently deceased.

item.title: Japan's huge army of under-employed ex-housewives
item.description: Why women are still battling for better jobs in the world's third largest economy.

item.title: In India, growing clamour to criminalise rape within marriage
item.description: An Indian court ruled that forced sex with a spouse is not rape. Campaigners say it's time for new laws.

item.title: Ethiopia's economy battered by Tigray war
item.description: Food prices are rising, the currency's value is falling and investor confidence is shaken.

item.title: Afghanistan: Black Hawks and Humvees - military kit now with the Taliban
item.description: As the insurgents swept through Afghanistan they inherited an arsenal of US-made equipment.

item.title: Agnes Sithole: The woman who fought South Africa's sexist marriage laws
item.description: Agnes Sithole became an unlikely hero after her husband of nearly 50 years tried to sell their home.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'my summer'
item.description: A selection of striking images from our readers around the world.

item.title: Turkey lockdown: Pigeon-keeping in Istanbul on the rise
item.description: The ancient art of pigeon fancying, popular across Asia, enjoyed a revival during the pandemic.

item.title: Herat under the Taliban: residents on the new rulers
item.description: People in Afghanistan’s third-largest city, Herat, explain how life has changed in recent weeks.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'Thousands more left behind...and feel terrified'
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet in Kabul says many people are still desperately trying to leave, as evacuations draw to a close.

item.title: 'We were hurt in bombs through no fault of our own'
item.description: Jennifer McNern lost both her legs and Margaret Yeaman was blinded in separate IRA bomb attacks.

item.title: Strictly: Why are South African dancers so popular?
item.description: As Strictly prepares to return to our screens next month another South African dancer has joined the professionals.

item.title: A country abandoned: BBC's John Simpson on Afghanistan
item.description: As foreign forces end their 20-year campaign, our world affairs editor considers what has been achieved.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taxi driver, shopkeeper: UK victims of Kabul attack
item.description: Relatives and friends of Mohammad Niazi and Musa Popal pay tribute after Thursday's blasts.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'I helped the US military, now help me save my family'
item.description: Afghans living in Texas plead for help to save the lives of loved ones left behind in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP. as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Victims' relatives still desperately search for news of loved ones
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani reports on the human cost of the Kabul airport attack.

item.title: Afghanistan interpreter: Getting plane out was 'happiest moment of my life'
item.description: Former Afghan interpreter Burhan and his family are now in the UK, after begging for help to escape.
